content: This report summarizes the USDA's efforts to establish a national animal traceability system for rapid disease outbreak response. Despite economic benefits, federal proposals face controversy within the U.S. cattle industry. The report discusses background on animal ID and traceability, reviews arguments for and against a national system, and outlines unresolved issues. Appendices provide a timeline of the U.S. National Animal Identification System and information on international organizations setting standards for animal health and trade. On February 5, 2010, Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack announced the revision of the U.S. National Animal Identification System (NAIS) to a new approach called Animal Disease Traceability. This new framework allows states and tribal nations to choose their own level of animal identification and traceability for livestock populations. However, all animals moving in interstate commerce must have a form of ID for traceability back to their originating state. The USDA is implementing a new Animal Disease Traceability framework for livestock moving in interstate commerce.
